review_title: Seaman then moved to Roustabout trying to get an ET position
pros: Work half the year and make decent money at the bottom when the oil field is booming you get good hours offshore, and premiums and bonuses. The food was decent and sleeping was decent to have your own room while your relief was working. Also stayed in shape pretty good running the decks.
cons: Lots of hard work and very hot days in the summer if you aren't use to working out side which I am just some people may see this as a con. It's Hard to move from the crane crew or rig crew into the maintenance crew. You will Work with same people everyday outside in the weather 12 hours a day for 3 weeks straight. Lots of cleaning and scrubbing with brooms and brushes. I Tried to get an ET position or electrical position due to I have an associates degree in Electronics and instrumentation and over a year of ET training on the rig that I documented but when positions came available I was never offered a position or a trainee position while the ETs and electricians wanted me to get a position.  I believe upper management should see who is ready to move up inside the company rather than someone who has never been offshore.

review_title: Travel the world, meet many new people and the job is never boring.
pros: Travel all over the world and opportunities to live or work overseas.  Work with all nationalities and learn firsthand the good and bad about various cultures and work ethics/approaches.   Advancement in the company is based on your own merit.  It takes a multi-discipline engineer to work on many diverse systems.  You are not limited to a specific field.
cons: Travel schedules are unpredictable and it is difficult to schedule and keep personal events.  Many birthdays, anniversaries, family/friend weddings, etc. have been missed due to erratic travel schedules.  Can be difficult to keep in touch with and keep lifelong friends.

review_title: Good Company when oilfield is booming
pros:
Great benefits, awesome 401k matching and competitive pay. They good about paying for travel and booking decent airlines tickets for crew changing (Supervisor positions).

Safety is the number one concern, they don't just say it, they really mean it. Everyone has the authority to stop the job at anytime if they feel uncomfortable without repercussion from supervisors. It's their number one safety tool!
cons:
Due to the oil down turn, they no longer pay for license advancement classes, which is why I can to Transocean from my previous employer. They use to be really good about paying for continuing education and Coast Guard license advancement classes, but they cut back a couple years ago.

They're policies and procedures are constantly changing and evolving which can be very stressful and confusing for the employees working on the rig. It seems like every time you come back to work something has changed. It's sometimes hard to keep up with.

review_title: Staying Afloat in Down Market at What Cost?
pros:
-Challenging work every day is different
-Crews are like second family great spirit among most teams
cons:
-Erosion of benefits which started before downturn
-Shore based management works for own interest not personnel on the rigs
-Constant drama and uncertainty no sense of job security

pros: Benefits are outstanding, respect for employees is great, offices are nice, senior management is approachable and affable. In addition, there is no micromanaging and there is trust in the workforce.
cons: There seems to be a lack of communication generally and few opportunities for employees to get to know each other and to network. Furthermore, there is reluctance to encourage travel, even when the relationships that can be built would help the organization. In other words, you are just a name and an email address if you are not given the opportunity to strengthen communication by travel to other sectors and divisions. (Of course, there is a large population of the company that does travel out of necessity, but some shore based positions would greatly benefit by the establishment of relationships beyond an email and an occasional telephone conversation.)

review_title: Oil Co. offers opportunity to see the world!
pros: Meeting people as I travel throughout the world.
cons: As with any company there are downsides. For Transocean it depends on your job. If you are in Projects, as I currently am, then you sacrifice time away from your family as 90% of you job will be on location. There are times when your family can visit, but there are projects that can be in remote and even dangerous parts of the world (i.e. Nigeria) that can drag out for six months to a year. Another down side for working with Transocean is the nature of the industry. Currently the industry can not hire people fast enough, but there will be a time when the market corrects itself and we could have a repeat of the 80's, early 2000's, but I guess this can be said for other industries.

review_title: PT Student Worker/Intern: HQ Corporate Legal Department Houston, TX
pros:
I really enjoyed working here part-time for a few months while I was in college.  The legal and corporate executives were very friendly people who allowed me to keep a flexible schedule around my classes.

In sum, I appreciated:
Friendly people
Flexible schedule - I created my own
Nice corporate office
Great central location 

My supervisor always made sure I put my academics first and would check in to make sure I had a good balance in my schedule between work and school.  I could take time off or change my work hours when I needed to - no questions asked.
cons:
No real big downsides that I can recall, however I was not employed full time or permanently so my experience is limited.

I imagine that if I worked in the C-suite over a long time could get boring?  I'm personally not a classic "corporate exec type".

job_title: Contracts and Proposals Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: A very interesting job. Your exposure to projects and assignments really depends on who the  Managers are at the time, which change often but also offer a sense of variety. Travel opportunities abroad are possible, especially if you get to the management level. Overall, a lots of great experiences and some of the best people in the industry to work with.
cons: Pay has not been competitive. Company politics and seniority still play a big role in compensation. Recent change in leadership and budgetary climate during the down turn leaves very little care for personal and professional development opportunities. The focus is on the company's bottom line, not the people. "Nothing personal, just business" - may not be that much of a con, but if you are looking for job security, catch the wave on the upturn and leave before the downturn.

pros: When working in the oil field. A separate family can be made.  I consider the people I've met over the years as part of my extended family.  I would also say that the pay use to be very good, however in recent times things have been cut including the pay along with incentives.  This will bite the company in the end.
cons: In recent years the company has begun to forget who makes the money for them. No more paid travel for certain positions and decreases in pay while the cost of living goes up makes unhappy employees.  Ever wonder why you can't get people to come back to work? Think of the reasons above.

pros: Best work,schedule,good safety trainings courses accomodation,good salary,friendly managers and co mates.

job_title: Manager, Corporate Planning in Houston, TX
pros: Good pay and benefits and generally nice people, though competence is a minor criteria for promotion, mimicking and praising your  boss being far more important.
cons: At the shore based HQS, it is almost  impossible to convince management to listen, much less act.  All authority resides at least two management levels above responsibility.  Managers are required to make most decisions and not allowed to delegate.  There is virtually no numerical analysis, most discussions about key issues start with " how do you FEEL?" .  Thus, most decisions are made by managers who don't have or don't fully understand the facts, and based on gut feeling rather than facts.

pros: This is not a bad company to work for in general. When times are good the workers are happy.
